segments.text: Oh, about a year ago, we were approached by representatives of the Snead family.
Could you spell that?
S-N-E-A-D. Of Georgetown, Texas and Austin.
They are involved.
as part owners of a small short line railroad and are very interested in the future of the railroad industry.

And they were looking for some way to help, as it were, revitalize the railroad industry in this country and thought, and I think very wisely, that an educational institution would be a place where one could get some leverage
So after some discussions, they decided to give us an endowment.
Actually, the Texas A&M Development Foundation, strictly speaking, they were given an endowment of somewhat over half a million dollars.
The purpose of this would be to establish the Snead chair in railway engineering in the civil engineering department.
Now, the funds...

What we would like to do, and what the purpose of the chair is, is to employ a professor who is widely known in the railway industry to establish a teaching and research program in the department in railway engineering.
The research program, of course, would address problems

of the railway industry could be economic problems, could be any kind of problem, the teaching program would enable us to graduate people who could go into the railway industry educated in the most modern and up-to-date engineering disciplines that impact or are important to the railroads.
The purpose of the funds
would be to augment the individual's salary, giving the chaired professor the time to develop these programs.
As you probably know, we have to justify all of the salaries that we pay with state-appropriated funds.
And so if we are able to pay a portion of the salary from other funds, then that
give that professor release time to do these other activities which we think are important.
So we're in the process of searching for someone, but we've had a problem.

The railroad and railway industry in one sense academically has been dormant for so many years that finding people who are qualified in all the senses of the word, that is who can work with the railway industry, know the problems, find out what the problems are, and then
lead the research and set up the academic program.
And on the other hand, can meet the qualifications for an academic position.
Those people are very few and far between.
And so we've so far not had a lot of success in finding them.
But we are continuing.
And in the meantime, we are going to attempt to set up some other programs that will at least get us started in this business while we continue our search for a professor.
Do railroads employ a lot of civil engineers?
Yes, civil and mechanical by and large.

There is, well for a long time there was no program in railroad, no academic program in railroad engineering anywhere except there was one professor at the University of Illinois who retired several years ago.
Programs are now beginning to come back in in railroads.
People are

coming to the realization that for certain commodities that railroads are by and large the cheapest thing you possibly can do as far as bulk commodities and also the transportation system is in place all over the country.
It's about to fall apart in certain places, but at least that we're not talking about having to
establish a brand new transportation system.
So with this, programs are beginning to come back in at certain academic institutions.
And we think that that's appropriate, and we want to get one going ourselves.
So that's where we're going with that.
We want to continue our search for the chair, for the person to occupy the chair, and yet at the same time get a program started.
Is there anything else that we need to touch upon before we close?
Well, I guess I can't think of anything.
I think you've had quite an inclusive list of questions there.
Well, I appreciate interviewing you.
Thank you.
I appreciate your interest and wish you the best in your activities.
Thank you.
